title: Delivering securely on data and AI strategy
summary: Most organizations feel the imperative to keep pace with continuing advances in AI capabilities, as highlighted in a recent MIT Technology Review Insights report. That clearly has security implications, particularly as organizations navigate a surge in the volume, velocity, and variety of security â€¦
body: Most organizations feel the imperative to keep pace with continuing advances in AI capabilities, as highlighted in a recent MIT Technology Review Insights report . That clearly has security implications, particularly as organizations navigate a surge in the volume, velocity, and variety of security data. This explosion of data, coupled with fragmented toolchains, is making it increasingly difficult for security and data teams to maintain a proactive and unified security posture.  Data and AI teams must move rapidly to deliver the desired business results, but they must do so without compromising security and governance. As they deploy more intelligent and powerful AI capabilities, proactive threat detection and response against the expanded attack surface, insider threats, and supply chain vulnerabilities must remain paramount. â€œIâ€™m passionate about cybersecurity not slowing us down,â€ says Melody Hildebrandt, chief technology officer at Fox Corporation, â€œbut I also own cybersecurity strategy. So Iâ€™m also passionate about us not introducing security vulnerabilities.â€  DOWNLOAD THE REPORT Thatâ€™s getting more challenging, says Nithin Ramachandran, who is global vice presideâ€¦

title: The Download: LLM confessions, and tapping into geothermal hot spots
summary: This is todayâ€™s edition of The Download, our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of whatâ€™s going on in the world of technology. OpenAI has trained its LLM to confess to bad behavior Whatâ€™s new: OpenAI is testing a new way to expose the complicated processes at work inside large language mâ€¦
body: This is today’s edition of The Download , our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of what’s going on in the world of technology. OpenAI has trained its LLM to confess to bad behavior Whatâ€™s new: OpenAI is testing a new way to expose the complicated processes at work inside large language models. Researchers at the company can make an LLM produce what they call a confession, in which the model explains how it carried out a task and (most of the time) own up to any bad behavior. Why it matters: Figuring out why large language models do what they doâ€”and in particular why they sometimes appear to lie, cheat, and deceiveâ€”is one of the hottest topics in AI right now. If this multitrillion-dollar technology is to be deployed as widely as its makers hope it will be, it must be made more trustworthy. OpenAI sees confessions as one step toward that goal. Read the full story . â€”Will Douglas Heaven How AI is uncovering hidden geothermal energy resources Sometimes geothermal hot spots are obvious, marked by geysers and hot springs on Earthâ€™s surface. But in other places, theyâ€™re obscured thousands of feet underground. Now AI could help uncover these hidden pockets of poteâ€¦

title: How AI is uncovering hidden geothermal energy resources
summary: Sometimes geothermal hot spots are obvious, marked by geysers and hot springs on the planetâ€™s surface. But in other places, theyâ€™re obscured thousands of feet underground. Now AI could help uncover these hidden pockets of potential power. A startup company called Zanskar announced today that itâ€™s uâ€¦
body: Sometimes geothermal hot spots are obvious, marked by geysers and hot springs on the planetâ€™s surface. But in other places, theyâ€™re obscured thousands of feet underground. Now AI could help uncover these hidden pockets of potential power. A startup company called Zanskar announced today that itâ€™s used AI and other advanced computational methods to uncover a blind geothermal systemâ€”meaning there arenâ€™t signs of it on the surfaceâ€”in the western Nevada desert. The company says itâ€™s the first blind system thatâ€™s been identified and confirmed to be a commercial prospect in over 30 years.  Historically, finding new sites for geothermal power was a matter of brute force. Companies spent a lot of time and money drilling deep wells, looking for places where it made sense to build a plant. Zanskarâ€™s approach is more precise. With advancements in AI, the company aims to â€œsolve this problem that had been unsolvable for decades, and go and finally find those resources and prove that theyâ€™re way bigger than previously thought,â€ says Carl Hoiland, the companyâ€™s cofounder and CEO.   To support a successful geothermal power plant, a site needs high temperatures at an accessible deptâ€¦

title: Why the grid relies on nuclear reactors in the winter
summary: As many of us are ramping up with shopping, baking, and planning for the holiday season, nuclear power plants are also getting ready for one of their busiest seasons of the year. Here in the US, nuclear reactors follow predictable seasonal trends. Summer and winter tend to see the highest electriciâ€¦
body: As many of us are ramping up with shopping, baking, and planning for the holiday season, nuclear power plants are also getting ready for one of their busiest seasons of the year. Here in the US, nuclear reactors follow predictable seasonal trends. Summer and winter tend to see the highest electricity demand, so plant operators schedule maintenance and refueling for other parts of the year. This scheduled regularity might seem mundane, but itâ€™s quite the feat that operational reactors are as reliable and predictable as they are. It leaves some big shoes to fill for next-generation technology hoping to join the fleet in the next few years. Generally, nuclear reactors operate at constant levels, as close to full capacity as possible. In 2024, for commercial reactors worldwide, the average capacity factorâ€”the ratio of actual energy output to the theoretical maxiumumâ€”was 83%. North America rang in at an average of about 90%. (Iâ€™ll note here that itâ€™s not always fair to just look at this number to compare different kinds of power plantsâ€”natural-gas plants can have lower capacity factors, but itâ€™s mostly because theyâ€™re more likely to be intentionally turned on and off to help meet uneveâ€¦

title: 'Superb piece of fielding!' - Stokes run out by Inglis

title: 'Gifted Australia a wicket' - Vaughan baffled by Brook dismissal

title: Bowler Wood casts doubt on fitness for third Test
summary: England bowler Mark Wood casts doubt on his availability for the third Ashes Test because of his knee injury.

title: British athletes given AI app as shield from online abuse
summary: British Olympic and Paralympic athletes are to be offered a new form of artificial intelligence-based protection from online abuse.

title: 'Excitement and nerves' for Archibald as Games loom
summary: Katie Archibald has already competed in a Commonwealth Games in Glasgow and is eager to do so again next summer.

title: Crawley falls for 76 as Australia make key breakthrough after lunch
summary: Zak Crawley is caught for 76 off the bowling of Michael Neser, ending a 117-run partnership with Joe Root to leave England on 122-3 on day one of the second Ashes Test in Brisbane.

title: Antetokounmpo injured as Bucks beat Pistons
summary: The Milwaukee Bucks beat the Detroit Pistons 113-109 despite losing two-time NBA MVP Giannis Antetokounmpo to injury early in the match.

title: Weekly sports quiz: Which keeper did Haaland score his 100th goal against?
summary: How much attention have you paid to what's happened in the world of sport over the past seven days?

title: Crawley reaches fifty as England fight back on opening day of second Test
summary: Zak Crawley brings up his half-century to help England recover from 5-2 to 98-2 at lunch on day one of the second Ashes Test against Australia in Brisbane.

title: 'I feared failure' - why Savage left club that 'saved' him
summary: Four years on from film crews witnessing Macclesfield FC's rise from the ashes, a new documentary follows Robbie Savage as he takes over as manager at the club he helped to create.

title: Watch trailer for Robbie Savage: Managing Macclesfield FC
summary: Watch the trailer for new BBC documentary Robbie Savage: Managing Macclesfield FC.

title: Robbie Savage takes on his first football manager job
summary: Robbie Savage takes on his first football manager job, but will he regret it?

title: Nomad Goods Promo Codes: 25% Off
summary: Save up to 25% on Nomad Goods accessories such as Nomad phone cases, Nomad wallets, and more this December.

title: OpenAI has trained its LLM to confess to bad behavior
summary: OpenAI is testing another new way to expose the complicated processes at work inside large language models. Researchers at the company can make an LLM produce what they call a confession, in which the model explains how it carried out a task and (most of the time) owns up to any bad behavior. Figurâ€¦
body: OpenAI is testing another new way to expose the complicated processes at work inside large language models. Researchers at the company can make an LLM produce what they call a confession, in which the model explains how it carried out a task and (most of the time) owns up to any bad behavior. Figuring out why large language models do what they doâ€”and in particular why they sometimes appear to lie, cheat, and deceiveâ€”is one of the hottest topics in AI right now. If this multitrillion-dollar technology is to be deployed as widely as its makers hope it will be, it must be made more trustworthy. OpenAI sees confessions as one step toward that goal. The work is still experimental, but initial results are promising, Boaz Barak, a research scientist at OpenAI, told me in an exclusive preview this week: â€œItâ€™s something weâ€™re quite excited about.â€ And yet other researchers question just how far we should trust the truthfulness of a large language model even when it has been trained to be truthful. A confession is a second block of text that comes after a modelâ€™s main response to a request, in which the model marks itself on how well it stuck to its instructions. The idea is to spot when anâ€¦

title: The Download: AI and coding, and Waymoâ€™s aggressive driverless cars
summary: This is todayâ€™s edition of The Download, our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of whatâ€™s going on in the world of technology. Everything you need to know about AI and coding AI has already transformed how code is written, but a new wave of autonomous systems promise to make the process â€¦
body: This is today’s edition of The Download , our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of what’s going on in the world of technology. Everything you need to know about AI and coding AI has already transformed how code is written, but a new wave of autonomous systems promise to make the process even smoother and less prone to making mistakes. Amazon Web Services has just revealed three new â€œfrontierâ€ AI agents, its term for a more sophisticated class of autonomous agents capable of working for days at a time without human intervention. One of them, called Kiro, is designed to work independently without the need for a human to constantly point it in the right direction. Another, AWS Security Agent, scans a project for common vulnerabilities: an interesting development given that many AI-enabled coding assistants can end up introducing errors. To learn more about the exciting direction AI-enhanced coding is heading in, check out our teamâ€™s reporting:  + A string of startups are racing to build models that can produce better and better software. Read the full story . + Weâ€™re starting to give AI agents real autonomy. Are we ready for what could happen next ? â€¦

title: Accelerating VMware migrations with a factory model approach
summary: In 1913, Henry Ford cut the time it took to build a Model T from 12 hours to just over 90 minutes. He accomplished this feat through a revolutionary breakthrough in process design: Instead of skilled craftsmen building a car from scratch by hand, Ford created an assembly line where standardized tasâ€¦
body: In 1913, Henry Ford cut the time it took to build a Model T from 12 hours to just over 90 minutes. He accomplished this feat through a revolutionary breakthrough in process design: Instead of skilled craftsmen building a car from scratch by hand, Ford created an assembly line where standardized tasks happened in sequence, at scale. The IT industry is having a similar moment of reinvention. Across operations from software development to cloud migration, organizations are adopting an AI-infused factory model that replaces manual, one-off projects with templated, scalable systems designed for speed and cost-efficiency. DOWNLOAD THE ARTICLE Take VMware migrations as an example. For years, these projects resembled custom production jobsâ€”bespoke efforts that often took many months or even years to complete. Fluctuating licensing costs added a layer of complexity, just as business leaders began pushing for faster modernization to make their organizations AI-ready. That urgency has become nearly universal: According to a recent IDC report , six in 10 organizations evaluating or using cloud services say their IT infrastructure requires major transformation, while 82% report their cloud envâ€¦

title: The Download: AIâ€™s impact on the economy, and DeepSeek strikes again

body: This is today’s edition of The Download , our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of what’s going on in the world of technology. The State of AI: Welcome to the economic singularity â€”David Rotman and Richard Waters Any far-reaching new technology is always uneven in its adoption, but few have been more uneven than generative AI. That makes it hard to assess its likely impact on individual businesses, let alone on productivity across the economy as a whole. At one extreme, AI coding assistants have revolutionized the work of software developers. At the other extreme, most companies are seeing little if any benefit from their initial investments.  That has provided fuel for the skeptics who maintain thatâ€”by its very nature as a probabilistic technology prone to hallucinatingâ€”generative AI will never have a deep impact on business. To students of tech history, though, the lack of immediate impact is normal. Read the full story . If you’re an MIT Technology Review subscriber, you can join David and Richard, alongside our editor in chief, Mat Honan, for an exclusive conversation digging into whatâ€™s happening across different markets live on Tuesday, Decâ€¦

Every Monday for the next two weeks, writers from both publications will debate one aspect of the generative AI revolution reshaping global power. This week, Richard Waters, FT columnist and â€¦
body: Welcome back to The State of AI, a new collaboration between the Financial Times and MIT Technology Review . Every Monday for the next two weeks, writers from both publications will debate one aspect of the generative AI revolution reshaping global power. This week, Richard Waters, FT columnist and former West Coast editor, talks with MIT Technology Review â€™s editor at large David Rotman about the true impact of AI on the job market. Bonus: If you’re an MIT Technology Review subscriber, you can join David and Richard, alongside MIT Technology Review â€™s editor in chief, Mat Honan, for an exclusive conversation live on Tuesday, December 9 at 1pm ET about this topic. Sign up to be a part here . Richard Waters writes : Any far-reaching new technology is always uneven in its adoption, but few have been more uneven than generative AI. That makes it hard to assess its likely impact on individual businesses, let alone on productivity across the economy as a whole. At one extreme, AI coding assistants have revolutionized the work of software developers. Mark Zuckerberg recently predicted that half of Metaâ€™s code would be written by AI within a year. At the other extreme, most companiâ€¦

title: The Download: spotting crimes in prisonersâ€™ phone calls, and nominate an Innovator Under 35
summary: This is todayâ€™s edition of The Download, our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of whatâ€™s going on in the world of technology. An AI model trained on prison phone calls now looks for planned crimes in those calls A US telecom company trained an AI model on years of inmatesâ€™ phone and vidâ€¦
body: This is today’s edition of The Download , our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of what’s going on in the world of technology. An AI model trained on prison phone calls now looks for planned crimes in those calls A US telecom company trained an AI model on years of inmatesâ€™ phone and video calls and is now piloting that model to scan their calls, texts, and emails in the hope of predicting and preventing crimes. Securus Technologies president Kevin Elder told MIT Technology Review that the company began building its AI tools in 2023, using its massive database of recorded calls to train AI models to detect criminal activity. It created one model, for example, using seven years of calls made by inmates in the Texas prison system, but it has been working on models for other states and counties. However, prisoner rights advocates say that the new AI system enables a system of invasive surveillance, and courts have specified few limits to this power. Read the full story . â€”James Oâ€™Donnell Nominations are now open for our global 2026 Innovators Under 35 competition We have some exciting news: Nominations are now open for MIT Technology Reviewâ€™s 2026 Innovators Uâ€¦

title: 'I deeply hurt people by moving to Saudi Arabia'
summary: In an interview with BBC Sport, Ashleigh Plumptre says she regrets losing the trust of some LGBT fans in women's football by moving to Saudi Arabia.
